thread.title: Former Goldman partner sees a ‘couple of more years’ of bull market
thread.title_full: Former Goldman partner sees a ‘couple of more years’ of bull market - MarketWatch

author: By     Victor Reklaitis
title: Former Goldman partner sees a ‘couple of more years’ of bull market
text:
With a bull market that is more than six years old, it is time to at least lighten up on stocks, right?
Not necessarily, according to Steven Einhorn, vice chairman of hedge fund Omega Advisors and a former Goldman Sachs GS, -0.24% partner.
“I happen to think that at least for the U.S., the in-place bull market that we are in will last a couple of more years. I think there’s quite a while to go before this particular bull market ends,” said Einhorn, speaking on an episode of the show “Wall Street Week” that aired Sunday.
“The fundamentals that largely determine how the stock market does are quite good, and I think partly overlooked by investors,” he also said.
Investors this year have focused on the Greek crisis and the timing of the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate hike, but what’s more important are how long the current business expansion will last, and how long the Fed will stay “friendly,” Einhorn said.
What’s more, the stock market historically has tended to gain for about 30 months after the first rate hike, he said. And while the current economic expansion looks to be the second-longest since World War II, that is not a fatal trait.
“Economic expansions don’t die of old age. They die of excess,” said Einhorn, who noted that is a cliché, but worth repeating.
The Omega Advisors vice chairman did recommend lightening up on certain sectors of the stock market, suggesting investors avoid consumers staples, which are relatively pricey, as well as materials, which are exposed to commodities and affected by the strong dollar.
What should investors buy? Einhorn particularly likes the health-care and tech sectors for their “open-ended” growth potential.
Go to “ Wall Street Week ” to see the full segment.
In May on the same show, billionaire activist investor Carl Icahn declared junk bonds are now “even more dangerous” than the stock market .
